questions.text: Best indicator of efficiency of contraception is ?
questions.solution:
The best indicator of the efficiency of a contraceptive method is the Pearl Index.

  • Pearl Index measures the number of accidental pregnancies that occur in 100 women-years of exposure to a contraceptive method.
  • It's widely used because it provides a straightforward, standardized way to compare the effectiveness of different contraceptive methods.

Interpretation:

  • A lower Pearl Index indicates a more effective contraceptive method (fewer pregnancies).
  • A higher Pearl Index indicates a less effective method (more pregnancies).

Incorrect Options-

Option (b): Life table analysis is another method used to evaluate the effectiveness of contraceptive methods, particularly over time. Unlike the Pearl Index, which gives an overall measure of effectiveness, it provides a more detailed look at the probability of contraceptive failure at different points in time, usually over months or years.

Option (c): The Corpulence Index is not related to the efficiency of contraceptive methods. Instead, it refers to a measure of body fat or body mass. Specifically, it is another term for the Body Mass Index (BMI), which is used to assess an individual's body weight relative to their height.

Option (d): The Chandler Index is not related to the efficiency of contraceptive methods. It is actually used in the field of parasitology. This is a measure used in parasitology to assess the intensity of parasitic infections, particularly in epidemiological studies. It is calculated by dividing the total number of parasites by the total number of hosts examined.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Pearl Index measures the number of accidental pregnancies that occur in 100 women-years of exposure to a contraceptive method.

TAGLINE: MODERATE

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, chapter-08, Page number: 570-578.

questions.text: Prophylactic dose of vitamin A given to 10 month baby is?
questions.solution:
The prophylactic dose of vitamin A for a 10-month-old baby is 1 lakh (100,000) units.

This dose is typically administered as part of the vitamin A supplementation program to prevent vitamin A deficiency, which can lead to serious health problems, including blindness and increased risk of infections. The dosing is done at specific intervals as part of public health initiatives.

Key Components of Vitamin A Supplementation Programs:

  1. Target Population:
    • Children: Typically, the focus is on children under five years of age, as they are most vulnerable to vitamin A deficiency. Supplementation is often targeted at children aged 6 months to 5 years.
    • Pregnant Women: In some programs, pregnant women may also receive supplementation to support maternal health and improve newborn health outcomes.
  2. Supplementation Schedule:
    • Routine Supplementation: Children receive high-dose vitamin A supplements at specific intervals, often every 6 to 12 months. The doses vary by age:
      • 6-11 months: 100,000 IU (International Units)
      • 12-59 months: 200,000 IU
    • Emergency Supplementation: During outbreaks of measles or in emergency situations, additional doses may be provided to prevent complications.
  3. Forms of Vitamin A Supplements:
    • Capsules: The most common form is vitamin A capsules, which are easy to administer and have a long shelf life.
    • Liquid Supplements: In some settings, especially where capsule use is impractical, liquid vitamin A supplements are used.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- The prophylactic dose of vitamin A for a 10-month-old baby is 1 lakh (100,000) units.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, chapter-11, Page number.:736-741.

questions.text: A center which covers a population of 5000 and multi-purpose workers are posted and can conduct delivery also. identify the type of center.
questions.solution:
The center described, which covers a population of 5000 and where multipurpose workers are posted and can conduct deliveries, is a Sub Center Type - B.

Options A, C and D are incorrect.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- The Center covering a population of 5,000 with multipurpose workers who can conduct deliveries aligns with Sub Center Type - B.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, chapter-10, Page number.:716-720.

questions.text: Most universally accepted indicator of health status of whole population and their socio economic conditions among the following is:
questions.solution:
The most universally accepted indicator of the health status of the whole population and their socio-economic conditions is: b. IMR (Infant Mortality Rate)

Infant Mortality Rate (IMR) is widely regarded as a key indicator because it reflects the overall health environment, including maternal health, access to medical care, socioeconomic conditions, and public health practices.

A lower IMR typically indicates better health care, higher living standards, and improved socio-economic conditions within a population.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Among these, IMR is the most universally accepted indicator of the overall health status and socio-economic conditions of a population.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, chapter-09, Page number: 640-645.

questions.text: In a survey it was reported that 45% of eligible couple are newly married couples in that area. All of them are willing to delay their first baby by 2 years. preferred contraceptive is?
questions.solution:
For newly married couples who wish to delay their first pregnancy by 2 years, the preferred contraceptive method would typically be one that is highly effective, reversible, and suitable for short- to medium-term use.

Given the options:

KEY TAKEAWAYS- For a couple planning to delay pregnancy by 2 years, oral contraceptive pills are often considered the most appropriate method due to their effectiveness, ease of use, and rapid return to fertility after discontinuation.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition,chapter-08,Page number.: 566-570.

questions.text: With increase in the no.of cases, 7 covid variant cases in China and Europe, international travelers are being checked at IGI airport so that the disease doesn't spread to the general population, correct match:
questions.solution:
The scenario described involves screening international travelers at the airport to detect potential COVID-19 cases. This type of screening is generally a preventive measure aimed at identifying cases early to prevent the spread of the disease.

Option A- Incorrect as prescriptive screening is secondary and not primary.

Option C - Incorrect.If the travelers are screened for early diagnosis and prompt treatment is done, then it is secondary screening.

But if the travelers are screened so that the general population is prevented from being exposed to the new variant, it is primary-prospective screening.

Option D - Incorrect as prospective screening is primary and not secondary.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- All the screening are secondary prevention except predictive/presumptive/prospective screening which is primary level of prevention.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, chapter-04, Page number: 152-158.

questions.text: 10-month-old child is brought to PHC with H/O cough and cold, running nose. On examination respiratory rate is 43/ min and no chest indrawing seen. Classify as per IMNCI guidelines?
questions.solution:
According to the Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Illness (IMNCI) guidelines, the classification of respiratory conditions in children is based on symptoms such as respiratory rate, chest indrawing, and general danger signs.

For a 10-month-old child:

  • Normal respiratory rate: Less than 50 breaths per minute.
  • Fast breathing (Pneumonia): 50 breaths per minute or more.
  • Chest indrawing or danger signs: Indicative of severe pneumonia or very severe disease.

Given the information:

  • Respiratory rate is 43/min (which is within the normal range for a 10-month-old).
  • No chest indrawing is observed.

This scenario fits the classification of "No pneumonia" according to IMNCI guidelines.

So, the correct answer is: a. No pneumonia

KEY TAKEAWAYS-Respiratory rate is 43/min (which is within the normal range for a 10-month-old) with No chest indrawing, This scenario fits the classification of "No pneumonia" according to IMNCI guidelines.

Reference: INTEGRATED MANAGEMENT OF NEONATAL AND CHILDHOOD ILLNESS (IMNCI),2023,Child Health Division,MOHFW,GOI, Page Number -19-26. https://nhm.gov.in/images/pdf/programmes/child-health/guidelines/IMNCI-Module-2023-For-health-worker/IMNCI-Facilitator-Guide-Health-Worker-2023.pdf

choices.text: Can be given at any age

questions.text: All are incorrect for BCG vaccine except:
questions.solution:
BCG (Bacillus Calmette-Guérin) vaccine is a Live vaccine.

Explanation of Each Option:

  • Option A: Can be given at any age: Incorrect. BCG vaccine is typically given at birth or in infancy, not at any age. It is commonly administered in the first year of life.
  • Option B: Intramuscular route: Incorrect. BCG vaccine is administered intradermally, not intramuscularly.
  • Option C: Live vaccine: Correct. BCG is a live attenuated vaccine used to protect against tuberculosis.
  • Option D: Distilled water as diluent: Incorrect. The BCG vaccine is usually reconstituted with a specific diluent provided with the vaccine, not distilled water.

KEY TAKEAWAYS-BCG is a live vaccine, administered via Intra -dermal route within first year of age.

Reference: Immunization_Handbook_for_Medical_Officers 2017,MOHFW,GOI, unit number:04, Page Number -19-26.

choices.text: Formation, extension, complete extension, dissolution, contraction, complete contraction.
Formation, extension, contraction, complete extension, complete contraction, dissolution
Formation, contraction, complete contraction, extension, complete extension, dissolution
Formation, extension, complete extension, contraction, complete contraction, dissolution

questions.text: Arrange the following stages of family cycle in chronological sequences:
questions.solution:
Stages of Family Cycle involves-

  1. Formation: The family is formed (e.g., marriage).
  2. Extension: The family grows with the addition of children.
  3. Complete Extension: All children are born, and the family is fully extended.
  4. Contraction: Children begin to leave the home (e.g., for work, marriage).
  5. Complete Contraction: All children have left the home, leaving only the original couple.
  6. Dissolution: The family dissolves, typically due to the death of one or both partners.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- The stages of Family cycle involves -. Formation, extension, complete extension, contraction, complete contraction, dissolution.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, chapter-12, Page number.: 792-798.

questions.text: If officer wants to do audit at subcentre, how many infants should be registered with health worker at that centre , if recorded birth rate is 20/1000 population:
questions.solution:
To calculate the number of infants that should be registered with the health worker at the subcentre, given a birth rate of 20/1000 population, we need to know the population covered by the subcentre.

Assuming a standard population coverage of 5,000 for a subcentre (which is typical in many regions):

  1. Birth Rate = 20 per 1000 population
  2. Population Covered by Subcentre = 5,000

Where:

  • Birth Rate is the number of live births per 1000 population per year.
  • Population Covered is the total population served by the subcentre.

So, the correct answer is 100

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Population in a subcenter is 5000.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, chapter-09, Page number.: 620-628.

questions.text: The most reliable criteria for assessment of growth development and nutritional status?
questions.solution:
The most reliable criteria for the assessment of growth development and nutritional status is Wt. for ht. (Weight for Height)

Weight for Height is particularly reliable because it assesses the proportionality between a child's weight and height, making it useful in identifying acute malnutrition (wasting).

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A: Weight for Age (Wt./Age) provides an overall picture of a child's nutritional status but has limitations in distinguishing between different types of malnutrition.
  • Option C-Weight for Height (Wt./Ht.) is particularly useful for assessing acute malnutrition (wasting).
  • Option D-Height for Age (Ht./Age) is a key indicator of chronic malnutrition (stunting).

KEY TAKEAWAYS: The most reliable criteria for the assessment of growth development and nutritional status is Wt. for ht. (Weight for Height)

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, chapter-09, Page number: 621-628.

questions.text: What is the best indicator to evaluate MCH care?
questions.solution:
The best indicator to evaluate Maternal and Child Health (MCH) care is: B. U5MR (Under-5 Mortality Rate)

  • IMR (Infant Mortality Rate): Reflects the number of deaths of infants under one year per 1,000 live births.
  • U5MR (Under-5 Mortality Rate): Reflects the number of deaths of children under five years per 1,000 live births. It is a comprehensive indicator of the overall health and well-being of children and the effectiveness of maternal and child health services, including antenatal care, immunization, nutrition, and disease management.
  • Stillbirth Rate: Indicates the number of stillbirths per 1,000 total births, reflecting antenatal and intrapartum care but not postnatal care.
  • Perinatal Mortality Rate: Includes both stillbirths and early neonatal deaths (within the first week of life) per 1,000 total births, focusing on the period around birth.

Under-5 Mortality Rate (U5MR) is considered the best overall indicator for evaluating MCH care because it covers the critical early years of life and reflects the cumulative impact of maternal health, neonatal care, and child health services.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Under-5 Mortality Rate (U5MR) is considered the best overall indicator for evaluating MCH care because it covers the critical early years of life and reflects the cumulative impact of maternal health, neonatal care, and child health services.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, chapter-09, Page number: 624-628.

questions.text: All activity are done under school health except?
questions.solution:
The activity that is not typically done under school health programs is Immunization

  • Option A. Eye check up: Commonly part of school health programs to identify vision problems.
  • Option C: Weekly Iron tablet supplement: Often included in school health programs to prevent anemia, especially in adolescent girls.
  • Option D. Deworming: Commonly done in schools to prevent parasitic infections.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Immunization is usually part of routine health services provided at health centers or during specific campaigns, rather than as a regular activity within school health programs.

Reference: NATIONAL HEALTH PROGRAMS OF INDIA, 12th Edition, J. Kishore, chapter-34, Page number: 666-671.

questions.text: All are types of screening EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
All are types of screening EXCEPT: D. Group screening

The common types of screening include:

  • Mass Screening: Screening of an entire population regardless of individual risk.
  • Multiple or Multiphasic Screening: Using several tests or procedures simultaneously to screen for multiple conditions.
  • Targeted Screening: Screening specific populations or individuals at higher risk for a particular condition.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Group Screening is not a standard term in the context of screening methods; it is often referred to as mass screening or targeted screening depending on the context.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, chapter-04, Page number: 151-159.

questions.text: Serial testing (Two or more tests for the same disease are applied in succession in only the positive samples) leads to an improved?
questions.solution:
Serial testing (applying two or more tests for the same disease in succession in only the positive samples) leads to improved:

B. Specificity

In serial testing, each test is applied only if the previous test is positive. This approach reduces the likelihood of false positives because only those who test positive on one test are subjected to further testing.

While this improves specificity (the ability to correctly identify those without the disease), it can reduce sensitivity (the ability to correctly identify those with the disease) because some true positives may be missed if they fail subsequent tests.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: In series- specificity increases but sensitivity decreases.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, chapter-04, Page number: 153-158.
